plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub admired for its large, showy flowers that bloom in winter. Its flowers range from white to deep red and often have a waxy texture. Camellias prefer acidic, well-drained soils and thrive in temperate to subtropical climates.
plants.location: Native to eastern and southern Asia; commonly cultivated in the southeastern United States and parts of Europe
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica was first introduced to Europe from Japan in the 18th century and became a symbol of elegance in Victorian gardens.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: A hardy, evergreen shrub known for its fragrant, showy flowers that bloom profusely in mild winter climates. Oleander is drought-tolerant and grows well in Mediterranean climates as well as subtropical regions.
plants.bloomingSeason: Spring to late autumn, but often still blooming in warm winter areas such as southern California and Mediterranean coastlines
plants.location: Native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Asia; widely cultivated in warm climates worldwide
plants.funFact: Although beautiful, all parts of the oleander plant are highly toxic if ingested.

plants.name: Prunus mume
plants.description: A deciduous tree treasured in East Asia for its fragrant, early-blooming flowers which appear in late winter or early spring. The delicate blossoms can range from white to pink and symbolize endurance and hope in Japanese and Chinese cultures.
plants.location: Native to China, Japan, and Korea; widely cultivated in temperate Asia
plants.funFact: The ume blossom is celebrated in many East Asian festivals and marks the transition from winter to spring.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: An Australian native tree known for its striking orange to golden flower clusters that attract birds and pollinators. It blooms in spring and sometimes during winter months in mild climates.
plants.bloomingSeason: August to December, occasionally into late December depending on local climate
plants.location: Native to eastern coastal Australia; cultivated in subtropical and warm temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Despite its name, silky oak is not an oak but is named for its timber's resemblance to oak wood.
